TEXT.TEXTVALUE: Choose an Anesthesia chamber of known volume. To obtain the volume of Isoflurane to be used in ml, multiply the volume by 0.15 to 0.2 ml.
The procedure should be conducted in a laminar air flow.
After placing the chamber of desired volume in the LAF, we proceed to the step where an Inhalant anesthetic agent will be used.
Open the Anesthesia chamber
Place a few cotton balls at the base of the chamber.
Take some Isoflurane using a dropper.
Pour Isoflurane of required amount on the cotton layer.
Place a raised floor over the cotton layer.
Close the lid of the chamber and let Isoflurane vaporize for 3-5 minutes.
Permit vaporization Isoflurane to flow through and fill the container.
Once the vapors have spread in the chamber, take the mouse from its cage and place it in the Anesthesia chamber.
Close the lid quickly after placing it in and then observe the animal.
The animal will move around for a while.
Within 1 minute, the mouse will fall unconscious (Anesthised).

Initially, respiratory rate will increase and then it gradually decreases. Allow the animal to become recumbent and reach slow and regular breathing. Allow the animal to remain at a deep anesthetic plane for 10 more seconds before proceeding.

After anesthising, pick the mouse and place it on an elevated surface.
Take a microhematocrit tube.
Introduce the end of the microhematocrit tube at the medial canthus of the orbit as shown.
Slowly, and with axial rotation, advance the tip of the microhematocrit tube gently towards the rear of the socket until blood flows into the tube. Collect the blood into a test tube.
Keep the test tube in a stand.
Dab the site of blood collection using a sterile cotton ball.
Restrain the animal in a restrainer.
Immerse the tail into warm water.
Rub the blood collection site using a cotton ball wet with 70% alcohol.
Visualize the sampling site of the lateral tail vein at approximately midpoint on the length of the tail.
Extend the tail with one hand, and with the other hand insert needle 3 to 4 mm into the lateral tail vein.
After collection, remove the needle from the tail vein and apply a gauze sponge with gentle pressure on the bleeding site to ensure hemostasis.
Collect the blood in a test tube as shown.
Restrain the animal in a restrainer.
Take a new scalpel.
After restraining the animal, rub the midpoint on the length of the tail with 70% alcohol wetted gauze sponge.
Visualize a sampling site of the lateral tail vein in the distal one-third of the tail. While extending the tail, swiftly incise the lateral tail vein with a new scalpel blade.
Collect blood drops into the test tube, required for the desired procedure to be performed with it.
Apply cotton with gentle pressure to the wound to ensure hemostasis.
Dispose the cotton into a Biohazard container.
Wrap a bandaid on the tail.
Place the animal in a recovery chamber that has proper air supply.
Animals should be observed until recovery is nearly complete and animals are able to maintain sternal recumbency or move about without falling.
Once you are sure the animal is back to the normal state, place it back in a cage. The time of recovery depends on the Anesthetic agent used and also the dosage strength.
